metadata.case_name: Appellant (Original Defendant) v. Vijay Kumar & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant executed mortgage on December 13, 1934 in favour of Tarabai, proprietor of the firm of Narayandas Chunilal.
Mortgage money secured became due on December 13, 1943 as per plaint, but High Court held it fell due on February 9, 1943 upon expiry of nine Fasli years without payment of installments.
Tarabai adopted Vijay Kumar on July 16, 1948 as a son to her deceased husband Motilal Hirakhanwala.
Tarabai died on April 23, 1952 leaving three daughters: Rajkumari, Premkumari and Mahabalkumari (mother of Vijay Kumar).
Vijay Kumar filed suit on February 9, 1954 to enforce mortgage as adopted son and sole heir of Tarabai, seeking foreclosure decree.
Appellant admitted mortgage but denied Vijay Kumar's adoption and right to sue, stating Tarabai's heirs are her three daughters.
District Judge, Aurangabad held adoption not established and dismissed suit on December 30, 1955.
Vijay Kumar appealed to High Court of Hyderabad (First Appeal No. 484 of 1957), transferred to Bombay High Court post-reorganisation.
On November 3, 1958, Vijay Kumar applied to add Mahabalkumari as co-plaintiff, Rajkumari and Premkumari as defendants, and amend plaint to alternatively claim for three daughters if adoption fails.
Bombay High Court allowed application on November 4, 1958, added parties and amended plaint.
Premkumari filed written statement denying adoption; Rajkumari did not appear.

Bombay High Court on November 17, 1959 allowed appeal, refused to decide adoption, dismissed suit by Vijay Kumar, passed preliminary foreclosure decree in favour of Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari.
Appellant appealed to Supreme Court under certificate granted by High Court.
Mortgage deed provided annual installments over nine Fasli years; non-payment of five installments entitled mortgagee to recover entire amount; no installments paid.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court order adding Mahabalkumari as co-plaintiff and Rajkumari and Premkumari as defendants under O.1 R.10 CPC was valid, or barred by limitation under S.22 Limitation Act.

Whether the suit by added parties is barred by limitation, considering change from Hyderabad Limitation Act (30 years, Art.133) to Indian Limitation Act 1908 (12 years, Art.132) via Part-B States Laws Act 1951.
Whether Art.147 or Art.132 of Limitation Act 1908 applies to the anomalous mortgage with foreclosure right.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order adding parties cannot be supported under O.1 R.10(1) as it adds both plaintiff and defendants; futile under O.1 R.10(2) due to S.22 Limitation Act deeming suit instituted on addition date (Nov 4, 1958), which is barred.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O.1 R.10 CPC; S.22 Limitation Act 1908

petitioner_arguments.text: Not a continuation of original suit; added parties press antagonistic claims to original plaintiff's; not representative capacity.

respondent_arguments.text: Question of Vijay Kumar's adoption should not be decided; decree should be passed in favour of added parties (three daughters) as heirs of Tarabai.
Proviso to S.6 Part-B States Laws Act 1951 continues Hyderabad Limitation Act Art.133 (30 years); or Art.147 Indian Limitation Act applies.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Part-B States Laws Act 1951 S.6; Limitation Act Art.133,147

court_reasoning.text: Addition under O.1 R.10(1) invalid as permits only plaintiffs, not defendants; adding plaintiff alone futile without sisters, as entitled jointly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sub-rule does not justify adding both; futile due to joint entitlement.

court_reasoning.text: Under O.1 R.10(2), S.22 Limitation Act applies; suit deemed instituted Nov 4, 1958 for added parties, barred by 12-year limit from Feb 9, 1943 under Art.132 Indian Limitation Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: New parties with antagonistic claims; not misdescription or representative suit.

court_reasoning.text: Indian Limitation Act 1908 applies post-1951; no vested right under Hyderabad Act; Art.132 governs foreclosure suit on anomalous mortgage, not Art.147.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Abridgment of limitation period does not impair vested rights; Privy Council in Vasudeva Mudaliar.

court_reasoning.text: Ravji v. Mahadev distinguished; S.22 applies regardless of sub-rule; policy prevents avoiding limitation via improper suit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Moyappa Chetty: defective suit by wrong party cannot benefit proper parties to avoid limitation.

holdings.text: High Court had power under O.1 R.10 and O.6 R.17 to add parties and amend, but addition results in suit barred by limitation under S.22 for added parties.
Suit by added parties (Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari, Premkumari) deemed instituted on November 4, 1958, barred under Art.132 Limitation Act 1908.
Art.132 applies to foreclosure suit on anomalous mortgage, not Art.147.

precedents_cited.relevance: Addition of defendants alone may attract limitation bar under S.22
Does not exempt S.22 for O.1 R.10(1) additions; limited to benamidar/real owner continuation

precedents_cited.case_name: Purshotam Umedbhai Co. v. Manilal Sons
precedents_cited.relevance: Correction of misdescription not true addition
Later Bombay cases not approving Ravji

precedents_cited.case_name: Vasudeva Mudaliar v. S. Shriniwas Pillai
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.147 applies only to English mortgages pre-1929 amendment
S.22 prevents proper parties avoiding limitation via defective suit by wrong plaintiff

precedents_cited.case_name: Subodini Devi v. Cumar Ganoda Kant Roy
precedents_cited.relevance: Overlooked S.22; no distinction between plaintiff substitution and defendant addition
S.22 deems suit instituted when new party added

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Addition/substitution of parties and amendment of plaint; power exists but subject to limitation

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems suit by added parties instituted on addition date; 12 years for foreclosure; not  English mortgage

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: 30 years for foreclosure, repealed 1951; no vested right continued

statutes_cited.name: Part B States (Laws) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended Indian Limitation Act; proviso does not preserve 30-year period as no vested right

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court decree in favour of Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari set aside as barred by limitation; trial court decree dismissing suit restored.
outcome.costs: Appellant will not get costs in any courts

key_quotes.text: "The addition of Mahabalkumari as plaintiff only would have been futile it would not have helped in the decision of any matter in dispute."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Sarkar CJ on why O.1 R.10(1) inapplicable

key_quotes.text: "Their Lordships are of opinion that s. 22 contemplates cases in which a suit is defective by reason of the person or one of the persons in whom the right of suit is vested not being before the Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quote from Moyappa Chetty explaining S.22 policy

key_quotes.text: "As regards Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari the suit must be regarded as instituted on November 4, 1958... the suit is barred by limitation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bachawat J holding on limitation bar for added parties
